script.speaker: Christopher
script.text: Lizzy, come sit down and talk to me for a minute. I got your email about the job offer and I'm not sure I'm comfortable with you taking it.

script.speaker: Elizabeth
script.text: What's not to be comfortable with, Dad? It's a great opportunity... it's exactly what I've been looking for in a career -

script.speaker: Christopher
script.text: -I know, but have you thought this through? You're going to be moving to the city, starting fresh. You don't know anyone there. What if you don't like it?

script.speaker: Elizabeth
script.text: That's the point, Dad. I need to get out of this small town and experience the world. I need to meet new people and build professional relationships. I'm 25, it's time I started my career.

script.speaker: Christopher
script.text: I just don't want you to rush into anything. You know, your mom always said you were impulsive -

script.speaker: Elizabeth
script.text: -Mom would understand why I need to do this. She always supported me, and you know she'd want me to take this chance.

script.speaker: Christopher
script.text: Okay, fine. But promise me you'll at least think about it some more, consider all your options. And don't forget to call me when you get to the city, I want to know you're safe... and that you're thinking about coming back to visit your old man.

script.speaker: Elizabeth
script.text: Of course, Dad... I'll think about it, but my mind is pretty made up. And don't worry, I'll call you as soon as I get settled.

script.speaker: Jalen
script.text: I don't get why you're still pursuing this whole 'being a professional artist' thing, sis. When's the last time you made any real money from it?

script.speaker: Yadira
script.text: That's not the point! Mom and Dad were always on our case about finding 'practical' careers, but I'm trying to follow my passion here-

script.speaker: Jalen
script.text: Passion, yeah... I get that, but you're 28 now, Yadi. It's time to be realistic. You can't just keep living off your savings and expect to make it big as an artist just because you're...unconventional.

script.speaker: Yadira
script.text: Unconventional? That's just code for 'weird' and you know it. Anyway, I've been doing some self-reflection and I've realized I need to stop trying to fit into what everyone else thinks I should be doing...I'm trying to be true to myself here.

script.speaker: Jalen
script.text: -I know, I know, 'be true to yourself'. But what about being true to your responsibilities? I mean, we're not kids anymore-

script.speaker: Yadira
script.text: Responsibilities? You mean like following in Mom and Dad's footsteps and getting a 9-to-5 job? No thanks. I'd rather be broke and happy than stuck in some office all day.

script.speaker: Jalen
script.text: See, that's exactly what I'm talking about. You're being reckless and impulsive... again. And what's with all these 'found art' pieces you're making now? They just look like a bunch of junk glued together to me.

script.speaker: Yadira
script.text: You just don't get it, Jalen... that's the whole point of art – to challenge people's perceptions and make them think. But I guess that's too much to expect from my 'practical' brother.

script.speaker: Richard
script.text: Come on, mom, why do you have to make a big deal about this? I'm just gonna wear this to the party.

script.speaker: Migdalia
script.text: Richard, that shirt is way too tight. And those pants are ripped. What would your abuela say if she saw you like that?

script.speaker: Richard
script.text: - mom, she wouldn't care. You're always so worried about what other people think. Can't you just let me wear what I want?

script.speaker: Migdalia
script.text: I care about what other people think because I'm your mother. It's my job to teach you how to present yourself. And, frankly, this getup is not presenting you in the best light. You look like you just rolled out of bed and threw on the first thing you found on the floor.

script.speaker: Richard
script.text: That's not fair. I put a lot of thought into this outfit. And, by the way, you're always saying how I should be myself and not care what others think... now you're contradicting yourself.

script.speaker: Migdalia
script.text: Richard, being yourself doesn't mean you have to look like a slob. There's a difference between confidence and laziness. And as your mother, it's my job to help you figure that out.

script.speaker: Richard
script.text: Whatever... I'm still wearing it.

script.speaker: Migdalia
script.text: Richard, if you walk out the door looking like that, I'm going to have to have a talk with you about your allowance...

script.speaker: Latoya
script.text: Roose, I need to talk to you about something. I know you've been having a rough time lately with school and everything, but I feel like you're not pulling your weight around here. I'm always the one reminding you about the rent and stuff.

script.speaker: Roosevelt
script.text: What are you even talking about? I've been paying my rent on time... I think. When's the last time you had to remind me?

script.speaker: Latoya
script.text: Last week, actually. And it's not just about paying on time - it's about helping out with household chores and stuff. It feels like I'm doing all the work around here. We're roommates, not mom and her kid.

script.speaker: Roosevelt
script.text: -Hey, that's not fair, Latoya. I've been doing stuff. I cleaned the kitchen last week-... didn't I? And I've been stressed out, okay? School's really kicking my butt right now.

script.speaker: Latoya
script.text: I get that, but you need to communicate with me about this stuff. I feel like I'm always walking on eggshells, waiting for you to blow up because I reminded you about something. We need to find a way to work together better.

script.speaker: Roosevelt
script.text: Look, I'm sorry, okay? I'll try to do better, I promise. But can we please not have this conversation right now? I have a exam tomorrow and I really need to study...

script.speaker: Latoya
script.text: No, no, it's fine. Study, I'll talk to you about it later. I'm just worried about us, about our living situation... about our friendship, I guess.

script.speaker: Roosevelt
script.text: Latoya, I appreciate that. Just... thank you for understanding, okay?

script.speaker: Lakeisha
script.text: Honestly, Lazaro, I've been really struggling to come up with ideas for my writing lately. I feel like I've been stuck in a rut.

script.speaker: Lazaro
script.text: Maybe it's because you're overthinking it, babe. Sometimes you just gotta write for the sake of writing.

script.speaker: Lakeisha
script.text: That's easy for you to say - you're not the one trying to make a living off of this. And it's also not just about writing for the sake of writing, it's about creating something meaningful.

script.speaker: Lazaro
script.text: - I know, I know, but sometimes I feel like you're too focused on trying to create something perfect -

script.speaker: Lakeisha
script.text: Lazaro, I'm not trying to create something perfect, I just... I don't know, it feels like everything I write is so shallow lately. Like I'm just regurgitating the same old ideas and it's not even inspiring me. And it's frustrating because I know I'm capable of more.

script.speaker: Lazaro
script.text: I think part of the problem is that you're comparing yourself to other writers too much. You're not them, you're you, and what makes your writing special is your unique voice.

script.speaker: Lakeisha
script.text: That's not it, Lazaro. I'm not comparing myself to other writers, I just feel like I've lost touch with what inspires me. Like, remember when we first met and we'd go on those long walks and have deep conversations about life and creativity? That's what inspired me, that's what made me want to write. But now it feels like we're just going through the motions.

script.speaker: Lazaro
script.text: Lakeisha, I know things have been busy lately, but that doesn't mean we can't make time for each other. And for our creativity. We can start going on those walks again, or doing whatever it takes to reignite your spark.

script.speaker: Lakeisha
script.text: I don't know, Lazaro... I just feel like I'm losing myself in all of this. And I don't know how to find my way back.

script.speaker: Thomas
script.text: I don't know, Patricia, I feel like mom's birthday dinner was kinda awkward...

script.speaker: Patricia
script.text: What's wrong with you? Can't you just be grateful that we're all still together, you know? Not everyone's as lucky as we are.

script.speaker: Thomas
script.text: - I am grateful, but -

script.speaker: Patricia
script.text: No, you're not. You're just being your usual selfish self, always looking for something to complain about... We were all having a good time, and then you had to go and bring up that old argument about dad's will.

script.speaker: Thomas
script.text: I wasn't trying to be selfish, it's just... it's still a big deal for me, and I thought since we're all adults now, we could have a more open discussion about it.

script.speaker: Patricia
script.text: Open discussion? You call that an open discussion? You just start yelling and expect everyone else to agree with you... And by the way, we're not kids anymore, but some things are just better left in the past, you know?

script.speaker: Thomas
script.text: I was not yelling... and I think it's weird that you're not willing to talk about it, since it affects you just as much as it affects me... I mean, we grew up in the same household, didn't we?

script.speaker: Patricia
script.text: Yeah, we did... but that's exactly why I don't want to revisit all that drama... Can't we just focus on the present and try to have some semblance of a normal family dynamic for once?

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: Osvaldo, why don't you take that jacket off, it's way too small for you, sweetie.

script.speaker: Osvaldo
script.text: No way, I just got it last week. It's cool.

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: - I know, I saw the pictures on your mom's phone. But trust me, you don't want to wear clothes that are too tight, it's not comfortable.

script.speaker: Osvaldo
script.text: It's fine, Ebony. You're just saying that 'cause you always give me weird advice.

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: I'm saying it because I care, kiddo. As your aunt, I want you to feel confident and look nice. And honestly, I think you'd look great in some of those new clothes your mom bought you.

script.speaker: Osvaldo
script.text: Mom said those are boring... Ebony, why are you always giving me compliments when I'm not doing anything?

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: What do you mean? I give you compliments because I think you deserve them, even when you're just being yourself. And that's what friends and family do for each other, right?

script.speaker: Osvaldo
script.text: But what if you're just being nice to me 'cause you have to? 'Cause we're related?

script.speaker: Lazaro
script.text: Trinh, can you tell me what's going on with this marketing project? You said it'd be done a week ago.

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: It's just taking a little longer than I thought, okay? I've been working on it, but...

script.speaker: Lazaro
script.text: -I don't want to hear excuses, Trinh. You're not just any employee, you're my daughter and you're representing this family's business. We need to see results.

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: That's exactly the problem - I'm not just any employee. You're always looking at me like I'm your daughter, not like I'm the marketing manager. You need to trust me, Dad.

script.speaker: Lazaro
script.text: Trust you? You're 25 years old, Trinh. You still live in the house I bought for you, and now you're questioning my business decisions? I think I know what's best for this company.

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: You bought this house for me because you wanted to, not because I asked you to. And maybe if you listened to my ideas instead of just telling me what to do, we could actually make some progress around here.

script.speaker: Lazaro
script.text: Progress? You call this progress? I built this company from the ground up, Trinh. I know what it takes to succeed.

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: That's exactly my point - you built it, but now it's time to let go a little. I'm not asking for complete control, I'm just asking for a chance to prove myself. Can't you just give me that?

script.speaker: Duc
script.text: Hey, Deandre, we need to talk. I felt really disrespected at my sister

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: What are you talking about? You

script.speaker: Duc
script.text: - didn't even apologize properly to my mom for being late to dinner. You just mumbled something and ran off to play with your phone...

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: Well, I was stressed out from work, and I didn't want to deal with anything else. Besides, your mom knows I love her, and I said sorry, didn't I?

script.speaker: Duc
script.text: That's not the point. You're my husband, and when we go to family gatherings, we need to be on the same page. If you can't handle your stress in a more considerate way, maybe we should talk about that too.

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: Maybe I had a bad day, okay? I'm trying my best here. And as for being considerate, whose idea was it to invite my mom over for dinner next week without even asking me?

script.speaker: Duc
script.text: That's not the same thing. Your mom lives alone, and we need to make time for her. Now, are you going to apologize to my mom or do I have to?

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: I'm telling you, Alex, as a journalist, I have a responsibility to tell the truth, even if it's not what the public wants to hear.

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: I get that, but-

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: -but what? You're my lawyer, aren't you supposed to be advising me on how to protect myself, not telling me to compromise my integrity?

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: I am advising you, but you need to understand the bigger picture here. We're not just talking about a simple libel case, we're talking about a multi-million dollar lawsuit that could ruin your reputation and your career.

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: And I'm saying that if I don't stand up for myself, for what I believe in, then what's the point of any of it?

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: I agree with you in principle, but we have to think about the practical implications. Can I get you a drink or something? You seem a bit... frazzled.

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: A drink? Really? You think a drink is going to fix this? Just be honest with me, Alex, as my lawyer and... as someone I care about. What do you really think I should do?

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: Honestly... I think we should try to negotiate a settlement. But I also think we need to be realistic about our chances of winning. And as someone who cares about you, I don't want to see you get hurt.

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: I appreciate that, but I still don't know if I can do it. It feels like I'm betraying everything I stand for.

script.speaker: Thu
script.text: Honestly, Luis, I don't get why you wear that bright yellow shirt on dates. It's kinda... eye-searing.

script.speaker: Luis
script.text: Ha, I like it. It's -

script.speaker: Thu
script.text: Being loud isn't the same as being stylish. We're not at a music festival, we're at dinner.

script.speaker: Luis
script.text: - outgoing. I'm an outgoing person, Thu, and my clothes should reflect that.

script.speaker: Thu
script.text: I'm not saying you're not outgoing, Luis, but... I dunno, I just think you have so many nice, simple shirts that would be more... you.

script.speaker: Luis
script.text: Simple shirts are boring. We've been on, what, five dates? Can't I wear something that shows my personality?

script.speaker: Thu
script.text: I guess what I'm saying is, I'm trying to get a sense of who you are, and when you wear stuff like that, it's... distracting. Can we please just talk about something else?

script.speaker: Luis
script.text: No, let's not change the subject. Look, I like your style too, even if it's not my thing. But if we're gonna make this work, you have to accept that I'm gonna wear stuff you don't always like.

script.speaker: Thu
script.text: I... I do accept that, Luis. I just wish, sometimes, you'd consider my feelings too. We're in this together, right?

script.speaker: Xuan
script.text: Roo, I'm telling you, the way they're pushing us to meet those quotas is insane. They're basically asking us to compromise on ethics.

script.speaker: Roosevelt
script.text: - I understand what you're saying, but, Xuan, we have bills to pay, just like everyone else. We can't just -

script.speaker: Xuan
script.text: No, no, you don't get it. It's not just about the bills. It's about the kind of reporting we're doing. We used to pride ourselves on telling the truth, no matter how tough it got. Now, it's all about sensationalism and getting clicks.

script.speaker: Roosevelt
script.text: I'm not saying that's right, but maybe we need to focus on finding a balance. I mean, you're not going to change the entire system overnight... You know how it is, we've been over this a thousand times in our career, and nothing seems to change.

script.speaker: Xuan
script.text: That's exactly my point. We've been doing this for years, and I'm starting to feel like I'm just going through the motions. I care about this job, Roo. I really do. But I care about our integrity even more. Remember when we first started dating, and we used to talk about making a difference with our work? I feel like we've lost sight of that.

script.speaker: Roosevelt
script.text: Of course I remember, Xuan. And I know how much this means to you, but sometimes I think you get so caught up in the idealism of it all that you forget about the reality. We have a mortgage to pay, and we're not getting any younger. Can't we just find a middle ground here?

script.speaker: Xuan
script.text: I don't know, Roo... I really don't know if I can keep doing this if it means sacrificing everything we believe in.

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: Hey Mei, what's with you watching so many comedy specials these days? You're starting to think you're a stand-up comedian or something

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: What, I just really like laughing and I'm trying to find some new material for when your dad comes over for dinner next weekend... you know to impress him with my wit

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: Oh, great. So now you're trying to be the office clown at my dad's expense? That's so not going to happen, I swear he's more corny than any comedian

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: Hey that's not true! Your dad's hilarious, and I love how he always tells those ridiculous dad jokes. Our friends love them too-

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: No-

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: -remember that time he told the one about the chicken and the egg at our anniversary party? Everyone was in stitches... well, except for maybe your cousin, she's always been a bit of a party pooper

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: Okay, okay, I get it. You're right, my dad's the real comedic genius here... Maybe we should just let him do the comedy and you can stick to the cooking, deal?

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: Deal, but don't think you're getting off that easy, I'm still going to practice my comedy skills in the shower and-

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: Great, just what I always wanted to hear, my partner screaming 'knock, knock' in the shower at 7 am

script.speaker: Sofia
script.text: I don't think it's a good idea, Lakeisha. You just graduated, you need some time to settle down before taking on a huge responsibility like that.

script.speaker: Lakeisha
script.text: Settle down? Mom, I've been preparing for this my whole life. I'm 22, not 18. And besides, this job is a huge opportunity... it's a career starter, really.

script.speaker: Sofia
script.text: -Lakeisha, let me finish. I know you're excited, but have you considered the work-life balance? You'll be working 12-hour days, 5 days a week. You won't have any time for yourself, or for us, for that matter.

script.speaker: Lakeisha
script.text: Us? You mean, like family? Mom, I love you guys, but this is about my future, not yours. And I've thought about the balance thing... I can make it work. I've seen your schedule when you were my age, it was way more chaotic.

script.speaker: Sofia
script.text: That may be, but your father and I had each other, we had... a system. And I wasn't 22, I was 25 when I started working like that. And I'm your mother, I'm supposed to worry.

script.speaker: Lakeisha
script.text: Exactly, you're my mother... so trust me, trust my judgment. I know what I'm doing, and I know what I want. This job is my chance to make a difference, and to make you proud, even if you don't agree with my choices now.

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: Ebony, sit down, let's talk about your cousin, Jamal. He's been staying with us for a while, and I know you're close, but some of the things he's been doing... it's just not right.

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: What are you talking about, Carlos? Jamal's fine, he's just going through a tough time.

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: A tough time? He's been stealing from the family business, Ebony. And I know you know about it, I've seen you covering for him. That's not decency, that's not what we do.

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: - But, Carlos, you don't understand, Jamal's in trouble, he owes people money...

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: And that's exactly why we can't keep covering for him. We have to think about what's right, not just what's easy. Family loyalty is important, but not at the cost of our values.

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: You're not even giving him a chance... you're just talking like grandma would, 'do the right thing'... but sometimes that's not that simple.

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: I'm not talking like grandma, I'm talking like someone who wants to see you and our family make it through this, with our integrity intact. Your mom would want that too.

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: Darius, I'm starting to get worried about your attitude towards your job at the newspaper. You used to be so passionate about it.

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: What do you mean? I love my job.

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: No, you don't. Not anymore. You're just coasting, Darius. I've seen your articles lately, and they lack the depth and integrity that I know you're capable of. -

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: - Come on, Cedric, I'm just trying to make a living here. Not every story can be Watergate.

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: That's not what this is about. It's about you selling out, Darius. You're a journalist, not a PR specialist. Your grandfather would be disappointed if he saw the way you're compromising your values... You know, I remember when -

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: Cedric, stop bringing up Grandpa. Just stop. You don't get to use him as a moral compass whenever it's convenient for you.

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: Convenient for me? Darius, I'm only trying to guide you because I care about your future. As your uncle, it's my responsibility to -

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: - responsibility? You mean like when you used to work late nights to meet deadlines? Or when you got that Pulitzer? I'm not you, Cedric. I have my own path to follow.

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: Your path? Darius, you're not even on a path right now. You're stuck in neutral, and it's breaking my heart to see it.

script.speaker: John
script.text: I don't get why you're so into this whole 'social media influencer' thing, it's just so... superficial.

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: Honey, it's not about that, it's about connecting with people and- -

script.speaker: John
script.text: -connecting with people? I've seen your posts, it's all just selfies and you posing in front of our bathroom mirror... You're a beautiful person, but that's not what you're showcasing.

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: That's not fair, you know I'm trying to build a brand. And I like taking pictures, it's fun for me... And I do showcase my interests, like that art piece I posted last week.

script.speaker: John
script.text: I remember, it was a picture of a sculpture and then you taking a selfie in front of it... Half the people who commented were just saying how great you look, not even mentioning the art.

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: Well, some people just like looking at pretty things... Besides, it's about being genuine and authentic, and if that means sometimes I get comments about my appearance, so be it... You're just not used to seeing me be myself, online.

script.speaker: John
script.text: I see you being yourself every day in our home, Deandre... That's not what I'm concerned about. It's just... I know you're more than just a pretty face, and I don't want you to get lost in all this.

script.speaker: Huy
script.text: I don't get why you have to tell your mom about us already?

script.speaker: John
script.text: What's the big deal? I was just talking to her about my week and it came up... it's not like I'm asking for her permission to date you or something

script.speaker: Huy
script.text: That's not the point - my point is why do you have to share everything with her? Don't you think that's gonna make things weird? She's gonna start expecting us to, like, visit her every weekend or something

script.speaker: John
script.text: Huy, come on... she's just excited for me, you know? And yeah, maybe we will visit her sometimes - I don't see the problem... we can still have our own thing, our own space, you know?

script.speaker: Huy
script.text: But that's just it - I don't want to have to worry about what your mom thinks, or have her always calling you, checking in... that's just too much for me, I need some space

script.speaker: John
script.text: -Huy, you're not even giving this a chance... we can set boundaries, I can talk to my mom about it... don't be so paranoid

script.speaker: Huy
script.text: I'm not being paranoid, John, I just know how these things go... and I don't want to get stuck in some situation where we're always having to consider your mom's feelings... that's just too much for me

script.speaker: John
script.text: Okay, fine... but can we at least talk about this some more? I feel like we're just getting started here...

script.speaker: Tameka
script.text: I don't know how much more I can take of this translation project, Cedric. The communication from the Tokyo team is still terrible, and now we're getting emails with contradictory deadlines.

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: Can't you just talk to them over the phone? Sometimes emails get lost in translation... no pun intended.

script.speaker: Tameka
script.text: Actually, phone calls are worse. I've been on calls where they just say 'ai, ai, ai' the whole time and I have no idea what they're agreeing to. And it's always something that they need 'yesterday'.

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: - Tameka, our home internet is slow again. I'll take care of it this weekend, don't worry about it, focus on your project.

script.speaker: Tameka
script.text: Cedric, this isn't about the internet. It's about how my job is going to affect our bills. If I don't get this project done on time, and to their satisfaction, I could be out of a job.

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: You're not going to lose your job, Tameka. You're good at what you do. Just ask for clarification on the deadlines and... what's that phrase you always say?

script.speaker: Tameka
script.text: I always say 'kyō made mo tsukiatte iru'... been getting by until now. It means we've been managing so far, but it's not good enough this time. I really need Tokyo's team to be on the same page as me.

script.speaker: Quang
script.text: Hey John, I wanted to talk to you about our block's community garden -

script.speaker: John
script.text: Oh, what about it? I thought we agreed to just have a small herb garden this year.

script.speaker: Quang
script.text: No, no, I know we did, but some of the other neighbors are getting a bit upset -

script.speaker: John
script.text: Upset? What do you mean?

script.speaker: Quang
script.text: Well, you've been putting in a lot of time over there, and some people feel like you're taking over, turning it into your own little business venture.

script.speaker: John
script.text: A business venture? You know that's not true, Quang. I'm just trying to help out. Besides, someone has to keep the garden running smoothly, and it might as well be me since I have the experience.

script.speaker: Quang
script.text: - John, just listen, okay? People are starting to feel like they're being pushed out. I've even heard some talk about canceling the whole thing if you don't dial it back a bit.

script.speaker: John
script.text: That's ridiculous. Fine, what do you want me to do about it?

script.speaker: Quang
script.text: I just want you to, you know, take a step back and let some of the other neighbors take on more responsibilities. We're all in this together, after all. We're a community.

script.speaker: John
script.text: You know what, Quang? You're right. I'll try to scale it back. But can we at least keep the herbal garden going? My wife has been really enjoying helping out with that part.

script.speaker: Quang
script.text: Of course, John. No one's saying we have to get rid of the herbs entirely. I'm just saying, let's work together on this, as neighbors.

script.speaker: John
script.text: Alright, alright. Let's work together. Thanks for talking to me about this, Quang.

script.speaker: Nghia
script.text: I'm telling you, our dad's jokes are the worst, Ebony.

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: Come on, they're not that bad. What's wrong with a little dad humor?

script.speaker: Nghia
script.text: A little? You don't remember that Christmas when he told the same knock-knock joke for like, an hour straight? I was dying

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: -Oh yeah, that one... I think mom was more annoyed than us, though.

script.speaker: Nghia
script.text: Right? And then he had the nerve to say, 'It's a classic!' Ugh, I'm still traumatized.

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: You're being dramatic, Nghia. It's just a joke.

script.speaker: Nghia
script.text: Just a joke? Just a joke?! You weren't the one who had to listen to him practice it in the car for three hours...

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: Alright, alright, I get it. Dad's jokes are the worst.

script.speaker: Nghia
script.text: Exactly. Finally, someone who understands me.

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: Don't get too excited, brother. I still think they're kinda funny.

script.speaker: Maribel
script.text: Trinh, I need to talk to you about something. It's been a while since you borrowed my favorite cookbook from Auntie Lan. When can I expect it back?

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: Uh, I'm sorry, ti Maribel... I don't know, I just forgot, I think it's still at my place

script.speaker: Maribel
script.text: Forgot? You borrowed it for that one dinner party, and now it's been months. I need it for the approaching Tet celebrations. Your mom wants to make banh chung

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: -I'm gonna go get it, ti, but why can't you just ask Mom where it is, she can give you the recipe... or just look it up online?

script.speaker: Maribel
script.text: Trinh, ti's recipe is passed down through generations, and it's not just about the recipe. It's about respect and consideration for others' belongings. You need to learn to be more mindful of other people's property

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: Sorry, ti... I'll go get it right now, but can I ask you something? Why do you always have to bring up stuff like that? It makes me feel like I'm still a kid

script.speaker: Maribel
script.text: Because, Trinh, as your ti, it's my responsibility to teach you about social etiquette and respect. And yes, you're still young, and you still have a lot to learn. Now, go get the book, and let's put this behind us

script.speaker: Richard
script.text: Tyrone, I'm getting worried about you, you've been coming home late almost every night, and I've noticed the smell of booze on you. What's going on?

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Nothing's going on - I just got a lot on my plate with work, and I need to unwind. I can handle my drink, Dad.

script.speaker: Richard
script.text: Unwind? You call getting drunk every night unwinding? I've seen your paychecks, and I know the kind of stress you're under, but this isn't the solution. It's affecting your performance, too - your manager called me yesterday.

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: What, so now you're monitoring my performance? - Come on, Dad, that's not the point. Performance anxiety is killing me. I don't know what you want me to do - I'm trying my best here.

script.speaker: Richard
script.text: I want you to try a different approach is what I want. Have you considered talking to someone about this anxiety? I can get you set up with a therapist... and maybe we can work on a new routine to help you deal with stress, something that doesn't involve drinking so much.

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Dad, I... I'll think about it, okay?

script.speaker: Rigoberto
script.text: Come on, you're not still upset about that stupid comedy club night?

script.speaker: William
script.text: Yeah, I'm still upset. You laughed at that terrible comedian the whole time and I was dying of embarrassment... -

script.speaker: Rigoberto
script.text: - dying of embarrassment? Really? That's dramatic even for you. I thought he was funny, okay?

script.speaker: William
script.text: Oh, so now you're the comedy expert? You were the one who dragged me to that awful show, don't forget... I mean our friends said it'd be a blast, but no-

script.speaker: Rigoberto
script.text: Wait, no, I'm not a comedy expert, I just know what I like, and yeah, our friends did recommend it. Besides, you have to admit that one joke about the cat was kind of funny... You're not going to hold this against me forever, are you?

script.speaker: William
script.text: Maybe... I don't know... It was just so awkward... But fine, I forgive you, this time. Just pick a better comedian next time, deal?

script.speaker: Rigoberto
script.text: Deal, and I'll try, but no promises... By the way, are you done unpacking the groceries? We've still got a bunch of stuff in the living room...

script.speaker: Mayra
script.text: Sang, I don't know why you're being so picky about my hair... it's just a color

script.speaker: Sang
script.text: Mayra -

script.speaker: Mayra
script.text: - I mean I know we're roommates, but come on, it's not like it's hurting anyone

script.speaker: Sang
script.text: I didn't say it was hurting anyone... I just thought that new hair color you put in wouldn't look so good on you

script.speaker: Mayra
script.text: So now you're a hairstylist?

script.speaker: Sang
script.text: No, I just... as your friend, I thought I should tell you

script.speaker: Mayra
script.text: A friend would give me a compliment, not insult my hair. 'Hey, Mayra, I love your new hair!' or something

script.speaker: Sang
script.text: But you know I'm not that type... and it's not like I don't think you look good -

script.speaker: Mayra
script.text: Whatever, Sang. Just keep your opinions to yourself

script.speaker: Sang
script.text: Fine

script.speaker: Luz
script.text: I'm totally wearing this to the birthday party tonight, Mom.

script.speaker: Barbara
script.text: Luz, sweetie, I don't think that outfit is really... well, I don't know, it's just not you, is it?

script.speaker: Luz
script.text: What do you mean it's not me? You're always saying I should express myself. This is how I'm expressing myself.

script.speaker: Barbara
script.text: I get that, but as your parent, it's my job to guide you. And I know your father and I - we didn't exactly raise you to wear certain... let's just say, revealing clothing.

script.speaker: Luz
script.text: So now you're gonna lecture me about Dad's opinions? He's not even here right now. This has nothing to do with him.

script.speaker: Barbara
script.text: -Luz, don't be like that. I'm just trying to have a conversation. You know your father and I want what's best for you.

script.speaker: Luz
script.text: No, what you want is for me to be this perfect, little girl who wears dresses and does everything you say. I'm not that person anymore, Mom.

script.speaker: Barbara
script.text: Luz, that's not fair... and it's not entirely about the clothes. It's about being respectful and considerate of others when you're out in public.

script.speaker: Luz
script.text: Whatever... I'm going to go get my jacket. I'll wear that over it if it makes you happy.

script.speaker: Barbara
script.text: Luz, wait! Just... let's talk about this some more, okay?

script.speaker: Yadira
script.text: Tyrone, I don't know if I can really do this, as our play's writer, I have a lot of emotional scenes to write, but collaborating with our director, it just feels like they're suffocating the project.

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: I get where you're coming from, but maybe you're being a bit too protective of your work... our director does have experience, after all. A little bit of creative control isn't going to kill you.

script.speaker: Yadira
script.text: - I know what she's doing, and it's not creative control, it's... it's dictating, and I just can't- It's not like I'm trying to be difficult. It's just that this play means a lot to me, and I want it to be something that I'd be proud to call mine.

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Proud? Okay, let's say you get your way, and the play is exactly how you envision it... as friends, can you honestly say we won't be sitting here a year from now, wondering why it tanked?

script.speaker: Yadira
script.text: That's not fair, we've talked about this, we both know that our director's decisions have already led to some... interesting choices. Like that one scene where the characters just stood there staring at each other for what felt like an eternity.

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Okay, okay, I see your point... I guess I'm just worried that if you keep butting heads with the director, you'll end up getting kicked off the project altogether.

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: Tamika, why didn't you tell me about your coworker's party before inviting them over to our home?

script.speaker: Tamika
script.text: I'm sorry - I thought you knew about Jennifer's get-together, I mentioned it that one time... well, I thought I mentioned it

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: - Actually, that's what I'm saying. You didn't, so I felt like I was put on the spot last night. We need to communicate better, especially with our social calendar getting busier

script.speaker: Tamika
script.text: I know, I know... I'll try to do better, I promise. Can you please forgive me for putting you in that awkward situation?

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: Of course, babe. I just wish we could've talked about it beforehand, you know? That way we could've, at least, prepared the living room and stuff

script.speaker: Tamika
script.text: I get it... And as my husband, I appreciate your input on these things. Maybe we can discuss and set some ground rules on hosting guests at our home?

script.speaker: Ulises
script.text: Come on, papá, I already told you I was gonna return it, why are you still mad about it?

script.speaker: Diego
script.text: Ulises, the problem here is not that you borrowed it, it's that you promised to return the book to our neighbor, Mr. González, two weeks ago and you still haven't done it -

script.speaker: Ulises
script.text: -fine, papá, I forgot, okay? It slipped my mind. But I'll return it today, I promise

script.speaker: Diego
script.text: Not just about returning it, it's about being considerate of other people's things. Mr. González was really looking forward to reading that book and now he's bought his own copy because he thought you weren't going to return it

script.speaker: Ulises
script.text: So now this is all my fault? He's the one who should have reminded me or something...

script.speaker: Diego
script.text: Ulises, as your parent, it's my job to teach you about social etiquette. And part of that is being responsible and respectful of other people's belongings. Your mother always reminds me to return things on time and I expect the same from you

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: Mom, I don't know why you're being so uptight about this, I just wanna wear my hair in a ponytail to school, that's it.

script.speaker: Lakeisha
script.text: Taylor, sweetie, you know the school has rules about that, and I don't like the way those boys -

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: What does that have to do with anything? This is about my hair, not those guys.

script.speaker: Lakeisha
script.text: Well, as your mom, it's my job to think about these things... and I just... I don't know, Taylor, you're my little girl, and I don't want you to look like you're trying to be a boy or something.

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: That's not fair, mom. I just like the way it looks, and that's it. Can't I just have my own style without you assuming I'm trying to be something I'm not?

script.speaker: Lakeisha
script.text: Taylor, stop being dramatic... I just want what's best for you, okay? And as your mom, I know what's best.

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: No, you don't, mom. You don't know anything about what I want. All you ever do is try to control me and tell me what to do... that's not being a good mom, that's just being bossy.

script.speaker: Lakeisha
script.text: Excuse me? I'm trying to have a conversation with you, Taylor... don't talk to me like that.
